Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery lekanis; interior glazed black; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of two women facing each other between a pair of sirens or sphinxes (only breast with added red of left-hand creature preserved); lower parts of both women with red on garments remain; incised blob rosette as filling ornament; faint brown dilute below.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The sherd possibly belongs to the same vessel as British Museum 1888,0601.784.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 473, no. B816)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 226, no. 9)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0777) (Phase 1)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 92, pl. 1, no. 24)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
